div.p: Enhancing Privacy through the Visual Design of Privacy Notices: Exploring the Interplay of Curiosity, Control and Affect
Agnieszka Kitkowska, Mark Warner, Yefim Shulman, Erik Wstlund, Leonardo A. Martucci
Behavioral outcomes influenced by many factors (e.g., individual characteristics, privacy concerns, beliefs; external factors exposure to stimuli)
About visual design (framing and control) and its influence on:
About psychological factors: a) Curiosity and its effect on comprehension
b) Affective state and its role in the attitude-behavior relationship
Covariates Concerns, trust, time spent on the policy page
Statistical analysis Univariate analysis of covariance
(disclosure and valence) Mediation & moderated mediation (the role
of affect on the relationship between trust, concerns and disclosure)
Control Valence significantly differed between control groups,
Interaction effect: valence higher among participants provided control and scoring higher in curiosity, F(1, 608)=7.2, p<.01, p
Ability to change settings increases comprehension , F(1, 306)=11.1, p<.01, p
Ability to change settings influences intention to disclose, F(1, 306)=12.7, p<.01, p
Curiosity has a significant influence on privacy comprehension, F(1, 608)=8.5, p<0.01, p
Significant role of covariates: privacy concerns, trust implying that stable factors are better predictors of behavioral outcomes
Privacy concerns mediate the relationship between trust and information disclosure, b=.97, t(618)=8.06, p<0.01, CI[.06, .20]
Valence moderates the relationship between trust and concerns (scores on valence lower than 2.71 result in more negative relationship between trust and concerns)
Use methods different than self-reports to measure affect (e.g., EEG)
Affording control perceived positively potential for usability
Privacy UIs: enhance curiosity and extend engagement time to improve comprehension
